title: 112_hr1021
content: The Act titled "Temporary Bankruptcy Judgeships Extension Act of 2011" extends the temporary office of bankruptcy judges in certain judicial districts. The Temporary Office of Bankruptcy Judges authorized by Public Law 109-8 is extended for specific districts until vacancies occur. The Temporary Office of Bankruptcy Judges is extended for specific districts until vacancies occur, including districts in New York, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Puerto Rico, South Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia, and Nevada. Vacancies in the office of a bankruptcy judge are subject to certain conditions. The Temporary Office of Bankruptcy Judges is extended for specific districts until vacancies occur, including districts in California and Delaware. Certain vacancies in the office of a bankruptcy judge in these districts will not be filled under specific conditions. Certain vacancies in the office of a bankruptcy judge in specific districts, such as Delaware, Florida, and Maryland, will not be filled under certain conditions, including occurrences more than 5 years after the enactment of the Act and resulting from death, retirement, resignation, or removal of a bankruptcy judge. Vacancies in the office of a bankruptcy judge for the district of Maryland occurring more than 5 years after the enactment of the Act, and resulting from death, retirement, resignation, or removal of a bankruptcy judge, shall not be filled. Other provisions of Public Law 109-8 remain applicable to temporary office of bankruptcy judges. Temporary office of bankruptcy judges extended by Public Law 109-8. The Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 1992 authorizes the extension of vacancies in the office of bankruptcy judges for specific districts until a vacancy occurs. For example, in the district of Delaware, the 5th vacancy occurring more than 5 years after the Act's enactment and resulting from specified reasons will not be filled. The Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 1992 allows for vacancies in the office of bankruptcy judges in specific districts to remain unfilled under certain conditions, such as in Puerto Rico and Eastern District of Tennessee, if the vacancy occurs more than 5 years after the Act's enactment and is due to specified reasons like death, retirement, resignation, or removal of a bankruptcy judge. The Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 1992 allows for vacancies in the office of bankruptcy judges in specific districts to remain unfilled under certain conditions, such as death, retirement, resignation, or removal of a bankruptcy judge. All other provisions of the Act remain applicable to temporary offices of bankruptcy judges. The temporary office of the bankruptcy judge authorized for the Middle District of North Carolina is extended until a vacancy occurs. Carolina's temporary bankruptcy judge office is extended until the first vacancy occurs, which will not be filled if it happens more than 5 years after the Act's enactment. Other provisions of the Bankruptcy Judgeship Act of 1992 remain applicable to the temporary office. The bankruptcy filing fee is increased from $1,000 to $1,042. Incremental amounts collected will be deposited in a special fund for specific purposes as specified in the law. This change will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act.
